REWARD OFFERED
The Johns Hopkins University, with the assistance of a
group of concerned alumni
and friends, is offering a
reward of $5,000 for information leading to an arrest and
conviction in the murder of
Bridget Bernadette Phillips.
Miss Phillips. 22, a firstyear graduate student in
history, was discovered in her
off-campus apartment in the

2800 block of North Calvert
Street on Thursday, March 23.
"We are all shocked and
outraged by this brutal act,"
said University President
Steven Muller. "Several
alumni and friends of the
University are joining us in offering this reward in the hope
that it will encourage anyone
who might possess relevant information to come forward to

the police."
Anyone who does have information bearing on the investigation of Phillips's death
can contact the Baltimore City homicide division at
(301)-396-2100. The Johns
Hopkins University reserves
the right to make the final
determination as to the person
or persons eligible to receive
part or all of this reward.

Getting to the heart of it
News-Letter

HOP director-elect Howie Fried had an interesting idea at this week's Student Council
meeting. He proposed that students pay, in addition to tuition, a Student Activities fee. This
fee, devised to increase the Student Activities
fund, would benefit the HOP and the various
clubs and organizations that fall under the
jurisdiction of the Student Activities Office.
Fried argues that the additional funds would increase and enhance both the quality and number
of social programs on campus.
We would be fools not to acknowledge the
logic in Fried's proposal. Money is, after all,
a scarce commodity at this university, and is
consequently always welcome, particularly at
the Student Activities Office. Channeling more
funds into its overburdened budget can only
serve to ameliorate the current situation.
The mechanics of this proposal remain, of
course, to be worked out. The deans would
have to work together to determine how to
direct these funds straight to Student Activities.
In addition, it is imperative that the fee be
used to supplement, not supplant, the existing
budget. Call us jaded, but the administration,
which already sees us as revenue raisers, would
be only too willing to thrust the financial burden
of Student Activities back into our laps.
However, there is more to the improvement
of social programming at Hopkins than simply money. For a tangible difference to be felt
in this realm, other factors need to be improved. It appears to us initially, at least, that
an increase in activities funds would ensure that
the HOP would have fewer difficulties in securing bigger names and better entertainment
events to book on campus. This line of logic,
however, leads us to an obvious stumbling
block—the dearth of facilities to house these activities. Both Shriver and Levering Halls are
relatively small venues; they are subject to
scheduling restrictions that boggle the mind,
due to their usage by every sector of the University, not just undergraduates. Those who try
to get around the shortcomings of the facilities
here often get shot down by the inevitable administrative reply: "That won't work here."
Attitude, then, has a lot to do with the success or failure of a program on campus. It is
hard to tell how the administration stands on

this issue. On the one hand, they value social
programming as an essential ingredient in that
ever-elusive "good environment" that they
seek. Yet, they go about it in a half-hearted
way. The money they do allocate to the program sinks in a quagmire of rules and restrictions. And innumerable guidelines, designed
mainly to protect the University from the
mistakes and mishaps of its students, often kill
events before they even get off the ground. Being a HOP director these days requires a user's
manual to make sense of the job's seemingly
endless limitations. As a result, the image of
campus events suffers. To quote Jane Gentil,
the HOP is not taken seriously. Forced by
University restrictions to limit severely the
number of alcohol events on campus, the HOP
often resorts to silly, obscure themes as a drawing point, a practice that often fails miserably.
While we do not advocate alcohol as a form
of entertainment, one must accept the fact that
it is a major drawing point for collegiate events.
One need only look at the two most successful,
weekly events of the year to verify this. Both
Funk Night and Hoppy Hour, which serve
alcohol, have enjoyed strong and loyal followings. Both events are also examples of inexpensive programming, belying the notion that
one needs money and fancy themes to attract
a crowd.
But what has hampered these successful attempts at programming has not been money;
it has been the aforementioned administrative
attitude and lack of available facilities. Hoppy
Hour has suffered from the overbooking of the
Glass Pavilion, and Funk Night has suffered
due to the paranoia of the administration.
If we put our ear to the ground, we hear
rumblings of campus life at other universities
of comparable academic ilk—those that are also
within states where the drinking age is 21. Student life can be improved to some extent by
throwing money at the problem. We are,
however, dangerously close to reaching a
saturation point: all of the money in the world,
and, for that matter, all of the clever programming ideas that enterprising students come up
with can make no difference unless structural
changes are made.

The Johns Hopkins Chapter of
the American Chemical Society
sponsored the seventh annual
Undergraduate Research Symposium last Saturday. April 1.
Following the keynote address on

group of undergraduate researchers had opportunities to give

The very distinguished keynote
speaker, Dr. Donald S. Coffey,
discussed the history and direction of cancer research. As a Professor of Urology, Professor of
Oncology, and a Professor of
Pharmacology and Molecular
Sciences, he is the first triple professor at Johns Hopkins. His lecture, entitled "New Concepts of
Cancer," described how cancer
research has grown over the past
fifty years and where it is headed. He began by describing a
benign tumor as 'anything that
grows in the body as a closed
fist." He continued the idea by
saying that "anything that looks
like a crab is invading [other cells
and organs]; it's malignant." Dr.
Coffey then went on to list many
cancers that seem to have cures,
or "exhibit complete retardation
upon treatment." These include
Hodgkin's disease, neuroblastoma, Wilm's tumor
and Burkitt's lymphoma. Dr.
Coffey explains that varieties of
cancer that don't have cures yet,

like lung and breast cancer, can
only be treated by removal if
found early enough.
An interesting characteristic of
cancer cells is that they "become
resistant to every treatment
made," whereas normal ce:ls do
not. Furthermore, the resistance
is apparent both in the "presence
and the absence of the chemical."
Another important characteristic
associated with cancer is that, due
to their genetic instability, each of
the cancer cells develop
"heterogeneity." This means that
each cell in a cancerous growth
has different genetic characteristics than other cells in.
that growth., although they all
came from the same original
cells. Dr. Coffey used an analogy
to explain this. Imagine, he said,
an apple seed taken from a crab
apple. When it's planted and the
tree comes up, you'll see red
delicious apples on one branch,
golden delicious apples on
another, '`crab apples over here,
and Washington State apples over
there!"
After conveying the importance

cells. Dr. Coffey described how
normal cells die regularly,

destruct. This is once again
related to the genetic instability of
the cancer cells. In normal cells,
"there is a code somewhere that
tells it to die." This apparently is
not the case in cancerous cells.
Dr. Coffey explains further that

this research led to the idea of
morphological instability in

'The DNA uses this backbone to

cells. The fact that cancer cells

cell in a mathematical equation.
This is important progress since
many more studies can now be
done with computer simulation of
cancer cell mobility.

Jays crush the Cavaliers, 12-3
Defense blanks Virginia for 29:25 in 2nd half
by Patrick Furey
The Virginia Cavaliers had to
know it was coming. They
couldn't possibly have thought
they could get away with upsetting Hopkins in the quarterfinals
of the NCAA Tournament. Surely, the top-ranked Blue Jays
would get their revenge.
Yet even the Wahoos couldn't
have predicted just how complete
that revenge would be. Johns
Hopkins dominated play on both
ends of the field last Saturday,
scoring five unanswered goals in
the first quarter and seven in the
second half to pull away for a
12-3 victory here at Homewood.
Virginia got off to a fast start,
as All-American midfielder Andy Kraus won the opening faceoff and Rob Schmaltz scored the
game's first goals just thirty
seconds into the first quarter.
Kraus's ability to control the
faceoffs had worried the Hopkins
coaches all week, but when he
was forced to leave the game with
an injury early in the quarter, the
Blue Jays took control.
"I thought we'd have trouble
against Kraus because he does a
good job of controlling the
faceoffs," said Hopkins Coach
Don Zimmerman. "But when he
went out in the first [quarter], it
allowed us to control the tempo."
The Jays' domination began at
the 1:40 mark of the first quarter,
when Matt Panetta fed Brendan
Kelly to tie the game. Panetta
added a goal of his own two

minutes later, and then Hopkins
began to pull away. Consecutive
goals by Joe Rzempoluch, Jeff
Ihm, and John Wilkens gave the
Blue Jays a commanding 5-1 lead
before the first quarter had
expired.
But the Hopkins offense fell
asleep in the second quarter as
they strayed from their game
plan, and failed to score for the
final 19:21 of the half. The
Wahoos failed to capitalize,
however, as Quint Kessenich and
the Blue Jays defense completely
shut down their scoring attack.
Though the Cavaliers scored with
just one second remaining in the
half to make the score 5-2,
Hopkins survived their scoring
lull without any serious damage.
The defense continued to
dominate in the second half,
recording their fourth thirdquarter shutout of the season.
Originally thought to lack depth
at the beginning of the season, the
Jays' defensive unit has emerged
as the finest in the country, led by
seniors Dave Pietramala, Greg
Lilly, Steve Ciccarone, ail(' Pat
Russell. On Saturday, they blanked the Wahoos for 29:25 in the
second half, allowing Hopkins to
pull away with seven unanswered
goals. When Virginia finally
managed to score with only
thirty-five seconds remaining in
the game, it was too late to keep
Hopkins from winning their fourteenth straight regular season game.
The Blue Jays spread the scoring around on Saturday, as nine

players scored goals. Brendan
Kelly and Mau Panetta led the
way for Hopkins with two goals
and an assist apiece. Joe Rzempoluch added two goals and
freshman Brian Lukacz made two
assists for the Jays.
Tomorrow Hopkins will travel
to Chapel Hill to face their biggest rival, North Carolina. Seven
of the last eight games these two
teams have played have been
decided by one goal, including
last year's 6-5 win by Hopkins
here at Homewood. The game
will be played on natural grass at
Kenan Stadium following
Carolina's annual Blue-White
spring football scrimmage.
Because the Blue Jays play and
practice mostly on artificial turf,
this could give the Tar Heels a
slight advantage, especially if the
grass is wet and chewed up from
the football game.
Carolina fell from third to fifth
in the polls last week after a 5-4
loss to Maryland at College Park.
Although they controlled the action on both ends of the field, the
Heels couldn't seem to score
goals. But their defense, which
had been struggling early in the
year, came into its own last week
and could spell trouble for
Hopkins, especially if the Jays
have trouble adjusting to the
natural surface.
Tomorrow's game will be the
fifteeth meeting between Hopkins
and Carolina, with the Blue Jays
holding a slim 8-6 series edge.

saves early on in the game to

next week against Western

Jays a spot in the MAC Finals on
May 6, and will guarantee that the
game be played at Homewood.

winning ways," says Anderson.

Getting to the heart of it
News-Letter

HOP director-elect Howie Fried had an interesting idea at this week's Student Council
meeting. He proposed that students pay, in addition to tuition, a Student Activities fee. This
fee, devised to increase the Student Activities
fund, would benefit the HOP and the various
clubs and organizations that fall under the
jurisdiction of the Student Activities Office.
Fried argues that the additional funds would increase and enhance both the quality and number
of social programs on campus.
We would be fools not to acknowledge the
logic in Fried's proposal. Money is, after all,
a scarce commodity at this university, and is
consequently always welcome, particularly at
the Student Activities Office. Channeling more
funds into its overburdened budget can only
serve to ameliorate the current situation.
The mechanics of this proposal remain, of
course, to be worked out. The deans would
have to work together to determine how to
direct these funds straight to Student Activities.
In addition, it is imperative that the fee be
used to supplement, not supplant, the existing
budget. Call us jaded, but the administration,
which already sees us as revenue raisers, would
be only too willing to thrust the financial burden
of Student Activities back into our laps.
However, there is more to the improvement
of social programming at Hopkins than simply money. For a tangible difference to be felt
in this realm, other factors need to be improved. It appears to us initially, at least, that
an increase in activities funds would ensure that
the HOP would have fewer difficulties in securing bigger names and better entertainment
events to book on campus. This line of logic,
however, leads us to an obvious stumbling
block—the dearth of facilities to house these activities. Both Shriver and Levering Halls are
relatively small venues; they are subject to
scheduling restrictions that boggle the mind,
due to their usage by every sector of the University, not just undergraduates. Those who try
to get around the shortcomings of the facilities
here often get shot down by the inevitable administrative reply: "That won't work here."
Attitude, then, has a lot to do with the success or failure of a program on campus. It is
hard to tell how the administration stands on

this issue. On the one hand, they value social
programming as an essential ingredient in that
ever-elusive "good environment" that they
seek. Yet, they go about it in a half-hearted
way. The money they do allocate to the program sinks in a quagmire of rules and restrictions. And innumerable guidelines, designed
mainly to protect the University from the
mistakes and mishaps of its students, often kill
events before they even get off the ground. Being a HOP director these days requires a user's
manual to make sense of the job's seemingly
endless limitations. As a result, the image of
campus events suffers. To quote Jane Gentil,
the HOP is not taken seriously. Forced by
University restrictions to limit severely the
number of alcohol events on campus, the HOP
often resorts to silly, obscure themes as a drawing point, a practice that often fails miserably.
While we do not advocate alcohol as a form
of entertainment, one must accept the fact that
it is a major drawing point for collegiate events.
One need only look at the two most successful,
weekly events of the year to verify this. Both
Funk Night and Hoppy Hour, which serve
alcohol, have enjoyed strong and loyal followings. Both events are also examples of inexpensive programming, belying the notion that
one needs money and fancy themes to attract
a crowd.
But what has hampered these successful attempts at programming has not been money;
it has been the aforementioned administrative
attitude and lack of available facilities. Hoppy
Hour has suffered from the overbooking of the
Glass Pavilion, and Funk Night has suffered
due to the paranoia of the administration.
If we put our ear to the ground, we hear
rumblings of campus life at other universities
of comparable academic ilk—those that are also
within states where the drinking age is 21. Student life can be improved to some extent by
throwing money at the problem. We are,
however, dangerously close to reaching a
saturation point: all of the money in the world,
and, for that matter, all of the clever programming ideas that enterprising students come up
with can make no difference unless structural
changes are made.

self-contained part of the whole,

programs possible. Everything a
division saves, it can keep and
spend on its own projects. Thus

Coffey speaks & students present research
by Manish Shah
The Johns Hopkins Chapter of
the American Chemical Society
sponsored the seventh annual
Undergraduate Research Symposium last Saturday. April 1.
Following the keynote address on
New Concepts of Cancer,— a
group of undergraduate researchers had opportunities to give
presentations about their research
projects.
The very distinguished keynote
speaker, Dr. Donald S. Coffey,
discussed the history and direction of cancer research. As a Professor of Urology, Professor of
Oncology, and a Professor of
Pharmacology and Molecular
Sciences, he is the first triple professor at Johns Hopkins. His lecture, entitled "New Concepts of
Cancer," described how cancer
research has grown over the past
fifty years and where it is headed. He began by describing a
benign tumor as 'anything that
grows in the body as a closed
fist." He continued the idea by
saying that "anything that looks
like a crab is invading [other cells
and organs]; it's malignant." Dr.
Coffey then went on to list many
cancers that seem to have cures,
or "exhibit complete retardation
upon treatment." These include
Hodgkin's disease, neuroblastoma, Wilm's tumor
and Burkitt's lymphoma. Dr.
Coffey explains that varieties of
cancer that don't have cures yet,

like lung and breast cancer, can
only be treated by removal if
found early enough.
An interesting characteristic of
cancer cells is that they "become
resistant to every treatment
made," whereas normal ce:ls do
not. Furthermore, the resistance
is apparent both in the "presence
and the absence of the chemical."
Another important characteristic
associated with cancer is that, due
to their genetic instability, each of
the cancer cells develop
"heterogeneity." This means that
each cell in a cancerous growth
has different genetic characteristics than other cells in.
that growth., although they all
came from the same original
cells. Dr. Coffey used an analogy
to explain this. Imagine, he said,
an apple seed taken from a crab
apple. When it's planted and the
tree comes up, you'll see red
delicious apples on one branch,
golden delicious apples on
another, '`crab apples over here,
and Washington State apples over
there!"
After conveying the importance
of genetic instability of cancer
cells. Dr. Coffey described how
normal cells die regularly,
whereas cancer cells do not self
destruct. This is once again
related to the genetic instability of
the cancer cells. In normal cells,
"there is a code somewhere that
tells it to die." This apparently is
not the case in cancerous cells.
Dr. Coffey explains further that

this research led to the idea of
morphological instability in
cancerous cells. In every "normal cell [nucleus], there exists a
structural backbone. . . called the
nuclear matrix." This matrix is
very important in handling all the
DNA that exists in the nucleus.
'The DNA uses this backbone to
code for proteins,''and this very
backbone is "out of whack" in
cancerous cells.
Another concept that is recently being studied "quite a lot deals
with the mobility" of cancerous
cells. The fact that cancer cells
can move distinguishes them
from most other cells. Dr. Coffey explained how scientists in the
Oncology Lab at the Medical
School, using Fourier analysis,
have described the motion of a
cell in a mathematical equation.
This is important progress since
many more studies can now be
done with computer simulation of
cancer cell mobility.
Another subject addressed in
Dr. Coffey's speech was the importance of thinking in research.
Dr. Coffey said that although he's
not the brightest of people, naying "failed the fifth gradc . and
graduated from a teachers' college in Tennessee" with
